original_title: Recreating The Quadrophonic Sound of the 70s
original_content:
For plenty of media center PCs, home theaters, and people with a simple TV and a decent audio system, the standard speaker setup now is 5.1 surround sound. Left and right speakers in the front and back, with a center speaker and a subwoofer. But the 5.1 setup wasnt always the standard (and still isnt the only standard); after stereo was adopted mid-century, audio engineers wanted more than just two channels and briefly attempted a four-channel system called quadrophonic sound. Theres still some media from the 70s that can be found that is built for this system, such as [Alan]s collection of 8-track tapes. These tapes are getting along in years, so he built a quadrophonic 8-track replica to keep the experience alive.
The first thing needed for a replica system like this is digital quadrophonic audio files themselves. Since the format died in the late 70s, theres not a lot available in modern times so [Alan] has a dedicated 8-track player connected to a four-channel audio-to-USB device to digitize his own collection of quadrophonic 8-track tapes. This process is destructive for the decades-old tapes so it is very much necessary.
With the audio files captured, he now needs something to play them back with. A Raspberry Pi is put to the task, but it needs a special sound card in order to play back the four channels simultaneously. To preserve the feel of an antique 8-track player hes cannibalized parts from three broken players to keep the cassette loading mechanism and track indicator display along with four VU meters for each of the channels. A QR code reader inside the device reads a QR code on the replica 8-track cassettes when they are inserted which prompts the Pi to play the correct audio file, and a series of buttons along with a screen on the front can be used to fast forward, rewind and pause. A solenoid inside the device preserves the clunk sound typical of real 8-track players.
As a replica, this player goes to great lengths to preserve the essence of not only the 8-track era, but the brief quadrophonic frenzy of the early and mid 70s. Theres not a lot of activity around quadrophonic sound anymore, but 8-tracks are popular targets for builds and restorations, and a few that go beyond audio including this project that uses one for computer memory instead.
title: 70年代のクアドロフォニックサウンドを再現するための8トラックレプリカプレーヤー
body: 記事の要約：70年代に一時期流行した4チャンネル音響システム「クワドロフォニックサウンド」を再現するプレイヤーを作成した。8トラックテープをデジタル化し、Raspberry Piを使用して再生する。8トラックのカセットローディングメカニズムやトラック表示、VUメーターなどを再現している。クワドロフォニックサウンドは現在はほとんど使用されていないが、8トラックは人気のあるリストア対象であり、コンピューターメモリなどにも使用されている。
titles: 70年代のクアドロフォニックサウンドを再現するための8トラックレプリカプレーヤー
アンティークな8トラックプレーヤーの要素を残しつつ、Raspberry Piを使用したクアドロフォニックサウンドシステム
現代のサウンドカードを使用した4チャンネル同時再生が可能なクアドロフォニックオーディオシステム
8トラックカセットのQRコードを読み取り、正確なオーディオファイルを再生するクアドロフォニック8トラックレプリカ
ヴィンテージな8トラックテープをデジタル化してクアドロフォニックな音楽体験を楽しむためのシステム
